div1.head: Report on Liver Tissue from Sr. Luis V. Corona by Henry R. Muller, September 18, 1923
div1.p:
REPORT ON LIVER TISSUE FROM SR. LUIS V. CORONA
Received Sept. 18, 1923

The gross specimen is a block of liver tissue about 2 x 2 x 1/2 cm.
It has a distinctly yellow appearance on the freshly cut surface. At one end
the liver is honeycombed with round and oval cavities varying from a fraction
of a millimeter to 2 mm. The material was received in formalin.

Microscopic: Three slides were received stained with hematoxylin
and eosin. A number of slides were prepared stained with Scarlet R, and
other frozen sections were prepared stained with hematoxylin and eosin.
Paraffin sections are in preparation.

The set of slides received and the hematoxylin and eosin slides pre-
pared are practically identical. Liver lobulation is poorly preserved, but
remains of liver cords can be distinguished. The liver cells are large and
slightly separated from each other. Nuclei cannot be distinguished, but the
entire cytoplasm takes a finely granular blue or purple stain. Approximately
half the number of liver cells are vacuolated. The vast majority are large
round vacuoles within the liver cells and occupy the larger part of the cyto-
plasm. A few smaller vacuoles are present in the liver cells of other
fields. These vacuolated cells have a slight tendency to occur in groups,
but these groups appear to have no constant relation to periphery or centre
of the lobule. These vacuoles, in the frozen sections stained with Scarlet
R, are filled with large, red, round globules (fat) completely filling the
vacuoles.

In addition to these intracellular vacuoles, there are large irregu-
lar defects in the tissue, bearing no constant relation to any portion of
the lobules, but occurring haphazard anywhere. They correspond to the holes
seen in the gross. These spaces remain empty in the Scarlet R sections and
resemble the gas spaces seen in gas bacillus infection.
Report on liver tissue from Sr. Luis V. Corona

In addition, there is a moderate increase of connective tissue
in the portal spaces around the bile ducts and blood vessels, but not extend-
ing around the lobules.

With the high dry power of the microscope the sections are found to
be abundantly sprinkled over with large bacilli staining blue. These are
found chiefly outside of the liver cells, but many are also present apparently
within the cells.

On the above findings we conclude that the material is in an advanced
stage of post mortem change. There is fat within many of the liver cells.
The size and shape of the fat globules correspond to those seen in alcoholic
fatty liver. The presence of the bacilli and gas vacuoles point to a gas
bacillus infection. A moderate cirrhosis is also present. Definite con-
clusions as to whether the liver came from a case of yellow fever are difficult
to draw, but the type of fatty change seems to be against the possibility of
yellow fever.
